Article.Abstract: Development of CD8 alphabeta CTL epitope-based vaccines requires an effective strategy capable of co-delivering large numbers of CTL epitopes. Here we describe a DNA plasmid encoding a polyepitope or "polytope" protein, which contained multiple contiguous minimal murine CTL epitopes. Mice vaccinated with this plasmid made MHC-restricted CTL responses to each of the epitopes, and protective CTL were demonstrated in recombinant vaccinia virus, influenza virus, and tumor challenge models. CTL responses generated by polytope DNA plasmid vaccination lasted for 1 yr, could be enhanced by co-delivering a gene for granulocyte-macrophage CSF, and appeared to be induced in the absence of CD4 T cell-mediated help. The ability to deliver large numbers of CTL epitopes using relatively small polytope constructs and DNA vaccination technology should find application in the design of human epitope-based CTL vaccines, in particular in vaccines against EBV, HIV, and certain cancers.
Article.ArticleTitle: Delivery of multiple CD8 cytotoxic T cell epitopes by DNA vaccination.
Article.Affiliations: The Cooperative Research Centre for Vaccine Technology, Queensland Institute of Medical Research, Brisbane, Australia.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease
FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Two doses of 50 ug plasmid in 50 ul PBS; 2nd Immunization given 2-3 weeks after the first

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Lung influenza virus titers (pfu/ml) were reduced in polytope (contains the epitope)-immunized mice by approximately 30%.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Two doses of 50 ug plasmid in 50 ul PBS; 2nd Immunization given 2-3 weeks after the first

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized with a plasmid encoding a peptide construct that included the epitope. Splenocytes were obtained three weeks after the second immunization. In other experiments, the immunogen was delivered by particle bombardment (gene gun). .

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Restimulated splenocytes from polytope (contains the epitope)-immunized mice lysed epitope-sensitized P815 cells, even in the absence of CD4 T-cell mediated help.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Two doses of 50 ug plasmid in 50 ul PBS; 2nd Immunization given 2-3 weeks after the first

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Splenocytes for T-cell response analyses were obtained three weeks after the second immunization. In other experiments, the immunogen was delivered by particle bombardment (gene gun); plasmid DNA was precipitated onto gold beads, coated into mylar sheets, then delivered into the abdominal skin of anaesthetized mice with a gene gun. .

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Restimulated splenocytes from polytope (contains the epitope)-immunized mice lysed epitope-sensitized P815 cells, even in the absence of CD4 T-cell mediated help. Co-delivery of a plasmid that encoded GM-CSF enhanced the response.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Two doses of 50 ug plasmid in 50 ul PBS; 2nd Immunization given 2-3 weeks after the first

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Challenge with the OVA-transfected EL4 murine thymoma (E.G7) was performed by injecting 10000000 cells subcutaneously in the nuchal region 6 weeks after vaccination; tumor weight was determined 10 days later. .

AssayInformation.AssayComments: OVA-transfected tumors inoculated into polytope (contains the epitope)-immunized mice weighed significantly less than control after 10 days.
